“Hey, I’m home!” Aaron said as he walked through the door of his family's home.

He had been away at college for past few months. It was a long drive but he was finally home for the summer. It had already been a year since it happened, since he had lost his mother and sister. It wasn’t in a car accident or because of cancer. Instead, it was a pandemic that robbed the entire world of its mothers, sisters, girlfriends, wives, daughters, etc. Every single woman on the face of the earth, all gone in a matter of days.

No one really knew where the pandemic came from, only that only the women were affected. Things were so different now, how businesses ran and everything. Aaron could still hear his mother nagging in the kitchen or the sounds of his sister.

The loss of those you love was hard no matter what the circumstances, but even the deepest cuts will heal with time. However, even with time and strong hearts like Aaron’s father who would say, “As long as we keep their memory alive, they will never be really gone,” there was still emptiness in the world that every living thing could feel.

As he walked through the house, he can’t help but smile as he passes pictures of his family when it was whole. The once unbearable pain had dulled over time; he could now talk about them and smile. He then looked out the window to see his father in the garden.

He walked outside and his father greeted him with a smile and a hug. “Hey the garden looks good this year.” Aaron says

“Yeah. I even expanded it a few feet to make it wider, added some corn too.” He says

The rest of the afternoon went by as usual; whenever Aaron would come home they would grill out and catch up. Ever since it happened they had gotten a lot closer. However, eventually the conversation leads to the current state of the world.

“So... How long do you think mankind has?” Aaron asks.

His muscles may tear and his tendons may rip of from his bones, but by grief he swore that he would make those damned 100 pull-ups if it killed him in the process! Yet he knew words and promises would not aid his impossible task. His breathing was laboured, pin-pricks tickled his agonized arms and a cramp that felt like a gator was busy gnawing his side was growing ever more painful in his ribs.

He was in a military aircraft-hanger which had been converted into a giant under-roof bootcamp gym and training facility. Timed Training courses, gym-equipment and shooting ranges covered its divided interior. Zack was currently in a small, privately enclosed, cubicle where around 13 men in green-camouflaged overall uniforms sat on the cold concrete floor, along with a Sergeant and Captain whom stood watching him. There was none of the usual jeering and insults hurled at him as soldiers usually do when they mocked their struggling comrades whom were less fit than they. Instead, all those present just kept a respectful, solemn silence a he struggled pathetically.

Zack finally reached his utter limit at the 57th pull-up. The "Will-breaker" as the soldiers of bootcamp called it with their usual logical slang, was a mere 2 meter high U-shaped pole structure implanted up-side-down into the ground. It sole purpose was to break the stamina of ensigns by forcing them to complete sets of a specific exercise which was one of the most difficult tests of agility and endurance known to the human body. Or in short: the humble Pull-up. Zack needed to complete 100 sets of them consecutively in order to avoid being discharged from his unit with which he had spent the last 3-years.

But he was failing. His arms started shaking, his lungs burned as if brimstone was within him and his fingers began slipping from the horizontal iron pole. With a final monumental effort he pulled for all he was worth...and for a moment it seemed as if his chin would surpass the bar. But then, as if all his strength was sucked from him, his hands let go of the pipe, and he fell onto the floor. There he sat exhausted and defeated, his life drained from him. For the first time in his military career, Zack's will had been broken bay the fabled Will-breaker.

Sergeant Mortiz put a hand on his shoulder: "It's Okay, corporal. You did your best; there is no shame."
